questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) typically manifests with radiating pain, paresthesias, and weakness. However, these symptoms are generally confined to the hand, specifically the palmar radial aspect, the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. Symptoms are often worse at night or after repetitive movements of the hand. The patient here does not have this pattern of symptoms. Additionally, a patient with CTS would not have pain in the neck or arm, weakness when extending the wrist (a sign of damage to the radial nerve or its corresponding cervical nerve roots), nor pain with Spurling's test.

B) INCORRECT:

A patient with degeneration of the spine between vertebral bodies C3 and C4 may experience damage to the C4 nerve root. If the C4 nerve root were damaged, a patient might describe pain and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of the neck or the interscapular region, difficulty elevating the shoulder, and/or dyspnea or shortness of breath, as C4 also innervates the diaphragm muscle.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient with syringomyelia would also likely present with radiating radicular pain, paresthesias, diminished reflexes, and weakness of the upper extremities. However, symptoms would be bilateral and usually include decreased sensation in a “cape-like” distribution secondary to the progressive compression and damage to crossing neural fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract. It would also manifest as flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy due to damage to the medial part of the corticospinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

A patient with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) may present with pain, paresthesias, and weakness of the upper extremity, often following overhead activity. However, rather than causing symptoms to one specific nerve root, TOS usually compresses the lower trunk (C8–T1 nerve roots) of the brachial plexus. In a patient with TOS, Spurling's test would not recreate the patient's symptoms because the test is relatively specific for damage/irritation of the cervical nerve roots rather than the brachial plexus. Furthermore, TOS often affects vascular structures as well; patients present with arm pallor, coldness, decreased pulses, and/or cyanosis of the affected extremity, none of which is present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has some characteristic symptoms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). She is in the typical age range for symptom onset (50–70 years) and presents with unilateral paresthesias and weakness. Classically, ALS manifests with symptoms of both upper motor neuron (e.g., increased muscle tone, spasticity, increased reflexes) and lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., flaccid paralysis, decreased reflexes, atrophy). Although possible, the majority of the patients do not report sensory dysfunction. This patient has pain and paresthesia that radiates from the neck distally to the arm and hand, indicating selective nerve root compression.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) CORRECT:

This patient has cervical radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation. Her radiating pain and paresthesias are caused by damage and/or irritation of the C6 nerve root, which innervates the radial aspect of the forearm and the thumb. These symptoms are reproduced with Spurling's maneuver, which has a high specificity for cervical radiculopathy. This patient's weakness results from damage to the same nerve root, as C6 provides motor function to the wrist extensors. C6 nerve root damage is also causing the decreased brachioradialis reflex in this patient, as C6 supplies motor function to that muscle.

Other possible causes of the patient's radiculopathy include cervical spondylosis or a tumor causing nerve root compression. Her neurologic symptoms may also be caused by infections that affect the peripheral nervous system such as herpes zoster and Lyme disease. The diagnostic workup includes MRI, which would show a laterally prolapsed disk with surrounding edema in the case of disk herniation.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathy

A herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.
questions.hint: The pattern of symptoms and exam findings indicate that a nerve root has been damaged.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower back pain for the past 2 weeks. The pain is stabbing and shooting in quality and radiates down the backs of his legs. It began when he was lifting a bag of cement at work. The pain has been getting worse, and he has started to notice occasional numbness and clumsiness while walking. He has hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 133/92 mm Hg. Peripheral pulses are palpable in all four extremities. Neurological examination shows 5/5 strength in the upper extremities and 3/5 strength in bilateral foot dorsiflexion. Sensation to light touch is diminished bilaterally over the lateral thigh area and the inner side of the lower legs. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the lumbar spine
Ibuprofen administration and follow-up in 2 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the lumbar spine is the first-line test for suspected vertebral compression fracture (e.g., history of osteoporosis). This patient does not have any significant risk factors for compression fractures. An x-ray of the spine has limited diagnostic value in patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation and is therefore not routinely recommended.

B) CORRECT:

MRI is a first-line test for diagnosing disk herniation with associated radiculopathy. In patients with progressive or severe motor deficits, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, or bilateral symptoms (as seen in this patient), an MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. In patients with disk herniation, T2 weighted MRI images typically show a hypointense disk with disk space narrowing and evidence of impingement or compression of a spinal nerve or the spinal cord (e.g., compression of the thecal sac, hyperintense edema of the spinal cord). If the patient has progressive neurological deficits, rapid assessment of the lesion is required and emergency surgical correction may be necessary.

While disk herniation is the most likely cause of this patient’s radiculopathy, an MRI would also help to rule out a neoplastic, infectious, inflammatory, or vascular etiology of his symptoms.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The desiccated disk at L4–5 is hypointense and the disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

Hatched green overlay: normal intervertebral disks

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the spine without IV contrast is the initial imaging study for patients with suspected vertebral injury following blunt trauma (e.g., fall from height). In patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation, a CT scan has limited diagnostic value as it is not the best imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures. This modality may be indicated if first-line imaging is unavailable, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management of this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic exercise (e.g., physical therapy) is part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive neurological symptoms and motor weakness should raise concern for a complicated disk herniation. Exercise could worsen this condition, so a complicated disease should be ruled out first in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Analgesia (e.g., ibuprofen) and follow-up are part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive bilateral neurological symptoms and motor weakness instead raise concern for complicated disk herniation, so further investigation is required before conservative treatment would be indicated.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset back pain and sensorimotor dysfunction in a specific spinal nerve distribution that are accompanied by radicular pain (shooting down the leg) on the straight leg raise test is highly suggestive of lumbar disk herniation (likely L4).

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The cerebellum is supplied by the posterior circulation, and a stroke in this region can be due to dissection of the vertebral artery as a result of trauma. However, cerebellar stroke usually manifests with unilateral signs of ataxia, which this patient lacks. In addition, a cerebellar stroke would not explain this patient's bilateral motor weakness, hyperreflexia of the ankles, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

B) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain that radiates to lower limbs is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's history of breast cancer, spinal imaging including MRI is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.
questions.hint: Two features specific to this patient's diagnosis are severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe, shooting pain in his lower back for the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the back of both legs and started after he lifted a concrete manhole cover from the ground. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch bilaterally over the lateral thigh area and lateral calf. Patellar reflex is decreased on both sides. The passive raising of either the right or left leg beyond 30 degrees triggers a shooting pain down the leg past the knee. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Involuntary contraction of the paraspinal muscles
Compromised integrity of the vertebral body
Inflammatory reaction in the epidural space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Involuntary contraction of the paraspinal muscles could be caused by a back spasm due to heavy lifting, which would present with back pain. However, pain would usually be localized and not radiate along a dermatome of a nerve root. Furthermore, decreased sensation to touch, decreased reflexes, and positive Lasègue sign would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory degeneration of the spine can be caused by spinal arthritis due to ankylosing spondylitis, degenerative osteoarthritis, or psoriatic arthritis, which could present with pain and stiffness in the lower back. However, pain is usually dominant at rest, improves with activity, and has a chronic duration rather than an acute onset after heavy lifting. Furthermore, decreased sensation to touch, decreased reflexes, and positive Lasègue sign would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

A compromised integrity of the vertebral body could be caused by pathologic vertebral fracture (due to osteoporosis or trauma), lytic metastases (cancer), or anterior wedge compression fracture due to Pott's disease (tuberculosis). These could present with acute back pain and L4 radiculopathy. However, this patient does not have any significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., older, chronic glucocorticoid use, postmenopausal female) or TB (e.g., immunosuppression, drug/alcohol abuse, congregate settings), nor does he have a history of significant trauma (e.g., fall from height), making vertebral fracture and Pott's disease unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous core of the intervertebral disk and is surrounded by a dense outer ring, the annulus fibrosus. Compression, tension, and shear and torque stresses on the spinal disk (as with heavy lifting) together with degenerative changes (e.g., dehydration) can lead to a tear in the annulus fibrosus, resulting in nucleus pulposus herniation into the vertebral canal with subsequent spinal cord and/or nerve root compression. This nerve impingement causes symptoms of radiculopathy, which differ depending on the level of herniation.
Image Description:

Left: normal anatomy of the intervertebral disc and spinal canal

Right: common disc pathologies

– Disc protrusion: protrusion of the nucleus pulposus through the annulus fibrosus
– Disc herniation/extrusion/prolapse: complete herniation of the nucleus pulposus through a tear in the annulus fibrosus
– Disc sequestration: extrusion of the nucleus pulposus and separation of fragments

E) INCORRECT:

An inflammatory reaction in the epidural space might be caused by an epidural abscess or bone metastases. Both could present with acute back pain and signs of spinal cord compression. However, the patient has no evidence of cancer. Furthermore, an epidural abscess would demonstrate point tenderness and constitutional symptoms (fever, chills) and is usually associated with risk factors such as IV drug use, diabetes, or immunosuppression. Additionally, the acute onset of symptoms makes both diagnoses unlikely.
questions.hint: Severe lower back pain radiating down the legs together with decreased sensation to touch, decreased reflexes, and positive Lasègue sign (pain when raising legs passively) is suggestive of lumbar radiculopathy. The association between heavy lifting and the onset of symptoms suggests an acute, mechanical mechanism of injury.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?

choices.text: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia
Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

B) INCORRECT:

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

E) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.
questions.hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with osteoarthritis comes to the physician because of severe lower back and left leg pain. She has chronic lower back pain that is usually well-controlled with ibuprofen, but 3 hours ago her back pain acutely worsened after she picked up her 3-year-old granddaughter. The pain radiates from her lower back over her left outer thigh and knee towards the top of her big toe. Physical examination shows a diminished posterior tibial reflex on the left side. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities and there are no sensory deficits. Steroid injection into which of the following anatomical locations is most likely to relieve her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Facet joint osteoarthritis is a common cause of lower back pain in older individuals. While this patient does have chronic lower back pain that is well-controlled with NSAIDs, pain that radiates down the lower extremity suggests a disk herniation rather than facet joint osteoarthritis as the acute cause of her symptoms. Injection of steroids around the facet joints may temporarily alleviate her chronic pain, but it would not address the cause of her acute symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation occurs when a tear in the tough outer part of the disk (annulus fibrosus) allows the gelatinous inner substance of the disk (nucleus pulposus) to protrude and compress nearby nerve roots. Surgical removal of the intervertebral disk may be considered in severe cases; however, a steroid injection into the disk would not improve her current symptoms of nerve root compression.

C) INCORRECT:

The subdural space is a potential cavity located between the arachnoid mater and the dura mater. This space does not exist under physiological circumstances because the arachnoid mater and dura mater of the spine are attached to each other.

Unlike in the spine, cranial arachnoid mater does not closely adhere to the dura mater, which is why the formation of a subdural space can occur in the brain (e.g., due to hemorrhage from ruptured bridging veins).

D) INCORRECT:

The subarachnoid space between lumbar vertebrae L3 and L5 is the target for analgesic medications in spinal anesthesia. It is commonly used in surgical settings in which general anesthesia is not necessary and causes complete loss of motor and sensory function below the level of injection. Steroid injection into the subarachnoid space would not be an appropriate treatment for this patient with disk herniation.

E) CORRECT:

Disk herniation can cause nerve root compression, as the nerve root exits the central nervous system through the intervertebral foramen. Steroid injection at the intervertebral foramen helps reduce inflammation and edema around the nerve root and spinal cord and can relieve nerve root compression and alleviate symptoms of disk herniation.
questions.hint: Acute worsening of back pain in a 65-year-old woman after lifting something should raise suspicion for lateral disk herniation. The radiation of her pain to the lateral left leg suggests radiculopathy due to compression of the L5 nerve root.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain and weakness in the lower extremities. The pain is worse with movement and improves with lying down on a flat surface. She was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis 6 months ago and is currently taking isoniazid and rifampin. Physical examination shows sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the lower-thigh, patella, and medial aspect of the right lower leg. Strength is 2/5 with knee extension and the patellar reflex is absent. An x-ray of the spine shows a paravertebral opacity with anterior wedging of the vertebral body. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically manifests with diminished sensation extending diagonally from the dorsolateral thigh over the lateral knee and the anterior leg to the dorsomedial side of the foot, including the medial toes. This pattern is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. In addition, an impinged L5 nerve root would not affect knee extension or the patellar reflex but would instead lead to impaired dorsiflexion of the foot due to impaired innervation of the tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus muscles.

B) INCORRECT:

S2 radiculopathy is relatively rare compared to other radiculopathies and may manifest with diminished sensation affecting the posterior aspect of the thigh, partly extending down to the posterior leg and the perineum. Moreover, affected individuals often have urinary or fecal incontinence and sexual dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically manifests with sensory deficits involving the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, anterolateral as well as the posterolateral lower leg, and the lateral foot, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Moreover, an impinged S1 nerve root would not affect the patellar reflex but would instead lead to diminished ankle jerk reflex in combination with difficulty walking on toes due to impaired innervation of the gastrocnemius, peroneus longus, and peroneus brevis muscles.

D) INCORRECT:

L3 radiculopathy typically manifests with impaired sensation extending from the mid-anterolateral thigh to the medial thigh just above the patella, unlike the deficits seen in this patient. While affected individuals may present with a reduced adductor reflex and/or a mildly reduced patellar reflex along with mild impairment of knee extension, impaired hip flexion and adduction is more characteristic of L3 radiculopathy.

E) CORRECT:

L4 radiculopathy characteristically manifests with sensory loss or paresthesia extending from the distal anterolateral thigh over the patella to the medial lower leg, as seen in this patient. Diminished knee extension would also be expected since innervation of the quadriceps is impaired. This patient's reduced patellar reflex further supports the diagnosis of impingement of the L4 nerve root as the underlying cause.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.
questions.hint: A history of radiculopathy symptoms in a patient with primary tuberculosis and x-ray findings of anterior wedging of the vertebral bodies and paravertebral opacity is suggestive of spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease).

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 day after the sudden onset of pain in her neck, left shoulder, and left hand while shoveling snow. The pain improves when she lifts her left arm above her head. She has no history of similar pain or trauma. She worked as an auto mechanic for 40 years and retired 10 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Muscle strength is 3/5 on elbow extension, wrist flexion, and finger extension of the left upper extremity. Triceps deep tendon reflex is 1+ in the left upper extremity and 2+ in the right upper extremity. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the index finger, middle finger, and radial half of finger IV of the left hand. The Spurling maneuver is positive. An MRI of the cervical spine discloses a lateral disc herniation. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by compression of which of the following nerve roots?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

C4 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia affecting the lower neck and shoulder girdle (e.g., cape-like distribution), which is not the pattern seen here. Moreover, damage to the C4 nerve root leads to scapular winging, a condition that can arise due to any lesion to the dorsal scapular nerve innervating the rhomboid muscles. Finally, C4 radiculopathy does not cause a reduction in any of the reflexes of the upper extremity.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

C5 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia over the anterior shoulder, which is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. Moreover, damage to the C5 nerve root leads to impaired function of the biceps and deltoid muscles as well as a reduction in biceps reflex, none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

C6 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia extending from the radial aspect of the forearm to the thumb and radial side of the index finger, which is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. Moreover, damage to the C6 nerve root leads to impaired function of the biceps and wrist extensor muscles as well as a reduction in biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, none of which is seen here.

D) CORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain or paresthesia extending from the dorsal medial forearm up to the fingers II–IV and in palmar fingers II–IV (ulnar half of II, III entirely, radial half of IV). Damage to the C7 nerve root leads to impaired function of the triceps, wrist flexor, and finger extensor muscles as well as a reduction in triceps reflex.

The dermatomes overlap with each other and vary widely among individuals. Therefore, it may be difficult to identify the affected root only via sensory patterns, even in severe cases. Although the distribution of the sensory deficits is useful for the diagnosis, deficits are often not as characteristic as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

C8 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia extending from the dorsal forearm to the dorsal and palmar area of fingers IV (ulnar half) and V, and the hypothenar eminence, which is not the pattern seen here. Moreover, damage to the C8 nerve root leads to impaired function of the finger flexors and does not cause a reduction in any of the reflexes of the upper extremity.
questions.hint: Disc herniation and cervical spondylosis are the most common causes of compressive cervical radiculopathy. Some cervical roots are more frequently affected than others.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening low back pain and weakness in the lower extremities. The pain worsens with movement and improves when lying down on a flat surface. The patient was diagnosed with postmenopausal osteoporosis 6 months ago and is currently taking alendronate. Physical examination shows sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the lower thigh, patella, and medial aspect of the right lower leg. Strength is 2/5 with knee extension and the patellar reflex is absent. Osteopathic structural examination shows pain that worsens with lumbar flexion, spasm of the lumbar paravertebral muscles, and hypertonicity of the hamstrings. An x-ray of the spine shows anterior vertebral displacement and disc space narrowing. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

L4 radiculopathy characteristically manifests with sensory loss or paresthesia extending from the distal anterolateral thigh over the patella to the medial lower leg, as seen in this patient. Diminished knee extension would also be expected since innervation of the quadriceps is impaired. This patient's reduced patellar reflex further supports the diagnosis of impingement of the L4 nerve root as the underlying cause.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

L3 radiculopathy typically manifests with impaired sensation extending from the mid-anterolateral thigh to the medial thigh just above the patella, unlike the deficits seen in this patient. While affected individuals may present with a reduced adductor reflex and/or a mildly reduced patellar reflex along with mild impairment of knee extension, impaired hip flexion and adduction is more characteristic of L3 radiculopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically manifests with sensory deficits involving the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, anterolateral as well as the posterolateral lower leg, and the lateral foot, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Moreover, an impinged S1 nerve root would not affect the patellar reflex but would instead lead to diminished ankle jerk reflex in combination with difficulty walking on toes due to impaired innervation of the gastrocnemius, peroneus longus, and peroneus brevis muscles.

D) INCORRECT:

S2 radiculopathy is relatively rare compared to other radiculopathies and may manifest with diminished sensation affecting the posterior aspect of the thigh, partly extending down to the posterior leg and the perineum. Moreover, affected individuals often have urinary or fecal incontinence and sexual dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically manifests with diminished sensation extending diagonally from the dorsolateral thigh over the lateral knee and the anterior leg to the dorsomedial side of the foot, including the medial toes. This pattern is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. In addition, an impinged L5 nerve root would not affect knee extension or the patellar reflex but would instead lead to impaired dorsiflexion of the foot due to impaired innervation of the tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus muscles.
questions.hint: In a patient with osteoporosis and x-ray findings of anterior vertebral displacement, a history of radiculopathy symptoms, pain with lumbar flexion, and hypertonicity of the hamstrings indicate spondylolisthesis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents to the office with a 3-week history of gradually worsening sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. She has also had trouble urinating for several days. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg.
Physical examination reveals:


4/5 muscle strength in the left lower extremity

2/5 muscle strength in the right lower extremity

+1/4 knee and ankle reflexes in the right lower extremity
Anal sphincter tone is reduced

A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan reveals a T-score of -3.0 SD. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

C) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in the knee and ankle, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain radiating to the lower limbs is characteristic of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disc herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's dual-energy x-ray scan results, she likely has postmenopausal osteoporosis and should undergo spinal imaging to assess for vertebral fractures.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.
questions.hint: Severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness are characteristic of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man reports a 6-month history of increasingly severe burning pain and paresthesia in his right inner thigh. The pain is constant and is exacerbated by his physical activity as a rower and by long rides in his small sports car. The pain does not radiate below the knee, and the patient has no sensory complaints. He does not recall any injury or trauma. A course of physical therapy was unhelpful.
On examination, he has normal range of motion of the right hip and no pain with flexion, abduction, and external rotation of the hip (FABER test). He has a negative straight-leg-raise examination, and his deep-tendon reflexes are symmetric in the lower extremities. Examination of lower-extremity strength reveals very mild weakness of the right hip adductors.
Radiographs of the hips are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lumbar nerve-root compression is a common cause of thigh pain and should be suspected when an individual has a normal range of motion in the hip. Distinguishing lumbar radiculopathy from musculoskeletal hip pain can be difficult, but the distribution of the pain is a helpful guide. Musculoskeletal hip pain does not usually radiate below the knee, and neither does the pain associated with L2–3 lumbar nerve-root compression. The more common lumbosacral nerve-root compression is associated with pain that radiates below the knee. Rowing is associated with an increased risk of lumbar nerve-root compression as a result of the repetitive flexion and extension of the spine. Adductor muscles are mostly innervated by the obturator nerve, which originates from the L2–4 posterior nerve roots.

Key learning point: Radiculopathy that results in discomfort at the medial thigh and adductor muscle weakness is most likely to originate from lumbar level L2.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Meralgia paresthetica results from compression entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. This is a purely sensory peripheral nerve, and patients with meralgia paresthetica describe numbness and paresthesias at the lateral and anterolateral thigh.

C) INCORRECT:

First sacral nerve-root compression is usually associated with posterior leg pain and not anteromedial pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Hip osteoarthritis is usually associated with pain localizing at least in part to the groin, reduced range of motion on examination, and abnormal findings on hip radiographs.

E) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome is characterized by pain and tenderness at the lateral hip overlying the greater trochanteric bursa. It is a consequence of tendinosis of the gluteus medius and minimus tendons, likely related to repetitive overload of the tendons.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old carpenter reports worsening numbness in his right hand and difficulty using his tools for the past several weeks. He says that the numbness affects his fourth and fifth fingers specifically and that he cannot grip a hammer with sufficient strength. He also describes a shooting pain from the right shoulder and along the medial side of the right forearm.
His vital signs, general physical examination, mental status, cranial-nerve examination, tone, and reflexes are all normal. He has mild weakness of grip and finger extension. There is no Tinel sign at the elbow. He has reduced perception of pinprick in the fifth finger of the right hand and the medial forearm. Gait and station are normal. There is no Babinski sign.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A key step in evaluating a patient with neurologic problems is to localize the presenting problem to either the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or the peripheral nervous system (anterior horn cells, peripheral nerves, neuromuscular junctions, and muscles). When patients have weakness, the examiner can distinguish upper motor-neuron problems from lower motor-neuron problems by examining the pattern of the weakness, as well as function and dexterity, tone, tendon reflexes, and other signs.

This patient’s symptoms and signs (a distal weakness pattern, sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm, and no upper motor-neuron findings on examination) suggest a peripheral or lower motor-neuron neuropathy.

Sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension and shooting pain from the shoulder to the hand is indicative of a C8 radiculopathy.

Key learning point: Sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension suggests a diagnosis of C8 radiculopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with an isolated ulnar neuropathy. Ulnar neuropathies are characterized by sensory loss limited to the hand, normal finger extension, and a Tinel sign at the elbow. Testing for Tinel sign at the elbow requires localization of the ulnar nerve in the groove between the olecranon process and the medial epicondyle of the elbow. The examiner’s index finger repeatedly taps the ulnar nerve, causing a tingling sensation in the ulnar distribution of the forearm and hand distal to the tapping point.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with stroke often have weakness in extensor more than flexor muscles and increased reflexes or tone, which indicates an upper motor-neuron lesion. This patient’s pattern of weakness together with his sensory symptoms points to a peripheral process.

D) INCORRECT:

A brachial plexus injury is unlikely to affect only the C8 muscles. Patients with superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumors often also present with Horner syndrome, a triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Horner syndrome indicates a problem with the sympathetic nervous system.

E) INCORRECT:

Median neuropathies, such as those that occur in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, manifest as sensory loss in the first three fingers.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman reports 6 weeks of tingling and numbness in the first three fingers of her right hand, as well as episodic pain and weakness in the hand and arm. She has no significant medical history.
On examination, she has a normal range of motion at the neck and no Tinel sign at the wrist. She has mild weakness of the right biceps, pronator teres, and brachioradialis. There is no weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles. She has sensory loss of the thumb and forefinger. The bicep jerk is absent, but the rest of the reflexes are normal. The patient’s physical examination is otherwise normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Cervical spinal cord injury/myelopathy from a C1 lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord injury is associated with myelopathic signs such as a Babinski sign, spasticity or pathologically increased reflexes.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic-level radiculopathy does not affect the hand.

C) INCORRECT:

C8 radiculopathy is associated with weakness of grip and numbness of the medial hand and forearm.

D) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is C6 radiculopathy. It is associated with weakness upon elbow flexion, numbness of the lateral hand and sometimes lateral arm, and reduction or absence of the biceps (and occasionally) brachioradialis reflex.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with hand numbness, biceps weakness, and an absent bicep jerk who does not have a Tinel sign is C6 cervical radiculopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

A patient does not have carpal tunnel syndrome if the weakness involves muscles proximal to the hand. The Tinel test has a positive likelihood ratio of 1.4 for carpal tunnel syndrome and a negative likelihood ratio of 0.8, suggesting that neither a positive nor a negative finding on this test markedly changes the pretest probability of this condition.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department (ED) reporting difficulty walking. She awoke this morning with lower back pain, which she has had before, but then throughout the day, she had difficulty lifting her legs, which she has never experienced before. When she had an episode of urinary incontinence, she became concerned and decided to go to the ED. She denies any problems with speech or vision and has not noticed any weakness in her arms. She is typically active and walks several miles every morning. She reports no recent injuries.
On examination, her vital signs are unremarkable, and her mental status and cranial nerves are intact. She has strong upper extremities with normal sensation and reflexes. In her lower extremities, she has 4/5 strength with hip flexion. Sensation is diminished in both inner thighs. Her legs appear to have normal tone, but her rectal tone is diminished.
What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for this patient?

choices.text: Plain-film radiograph of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated in this case, as there is no reason to suspect infection or hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

Although CT can demonstrate a herniated disk and plain-film radiographs are helpful for identifying fractures, neither modality is adequately sensitive for identifying spinal-cord or nerve-root damage, infections, or tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Although CT can demonstrate a herniated disk and plain-film radiographs are helpful for identifying fractures, neither modality is adequately sensitive for identifying spinal-cord or nerve-root damage, infections, or tumors.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings localize to the cauda equina. Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is usually related to lumbar disc pathology but can also be the result of spinal stenosis, tumor, infection, or injury. It should be treated as a neurologic emergency to prevent permanent symptoms. It classically manifests with back pain, leg weakness, bowel or bladder sphincter dysfunction, and sensory abnormalities involving the inner thigh.

Patients with suspected CES should undergo urgent MRI of the lumbar spine, followed by consultation with a neurosurgeon if compression is present. MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for evaluating the spinal cord and nerve roots.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute-onset back pain, lower-extremity weakness, sensory changes, urinary incontinence, and loss of rectal tone, the most appropriate initial diagnostic test is urgent MRI of the lumbar spine, followed by neurosurgical consultation for possible cauda equina syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

A nerve-conduction study is not typically helpful in the acute setting because it may not show abnormalities early on in the disease course.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman reports low back pain and pain that radiates down her right leg to the top of her foot. The pain began suddenly one week ago during a strength-training class. She describes it as a moderately severe, deep, aching pain that is worsened by coughing, sneezing, and physical activity. Ibuprofen provides partial relief. She reports no weakness or numbness in her legs and no bowel or bladder dysfunction.
On neurologic examination, she has normal muscle bulk, tone, and strength with preserved sensation.
Which one of the following physical examination maneuvers is most sensitive for the likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Patellar reflex (percussion of the patellar tendon)
Straight-leg raise (flexion of the affected hip with knee extended)
Contralateral straight-leg raise (flexion of the unaffected hip with the knee extended)
Plantar reflex (stimulation of the sole of the foot with a blunt instrument)
Obturator sign (flexion and internal rotation of the hip)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patellar, or knee-jerk, reflex can be affected by pathology of the L2–4 nerve-root levels; the Achilles, or ankle-jerk, reflex is affected by pathology of the S1–2 nerve-root levels. Neither would be expected to be abnormal in an L5 radiculopathy, which is the most common lumbar radiculopathy and also the most consistent with this patient’s pain distribution.

B) CORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation is the most common cause of sciatica, a term that describes leg pain along a sciatic nerve or radicular distribution, often in the setting of low back pain. On physical examination, a positive straight-leg-raise test is sensitive (although not specific) for disk herniation. The test is considered positive if sciatica (radicular pain extending to below the knee) is reproduced when the affected hip is flexed to 30 to 70 degrees with the knee extended.

If a patient’s symptoms, history, and physical examination are consistent with an uncomplicated lumbar disk herniation (i.e., there is no history of intravenous drug use, fever, an immunocompromised state, suspected malignancy, or fecal or urinary incontinence and no severe neurologic deficits on examination), immediate imaging is not required, and a 4- to 6-week trial of conservative management with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and exercise-based physical therapy can be undertaken.

Key learning point: The straight-leg-raise maneuver is a sensitive physical examination maneuver for lumbar disk herniation.

C) INCORRECT:

The contralateral straight-leg-raise test (flexion of the unaffected hip with the knee extended) is specific for lumbar radiculopathy but is not as sensitive as the straight-leg-raise test.

D) INCORRECT:

An extensor response to the plantar reflex, whereby the big toe moves superiorly and the other toes fan out in response to the sole of the foot being stroked with a blunt instrument, is a sign of corticospinal tract pathology (an upper motor-neuron pathology), which is not expected in cases of lumbar disk herniation (a lower motor-neuron pathology).

E) INCORRECT:

The obturator sign is an examination maneuver for appendicitis. Flexing and internally rotating the right hip can lead to pain if the inflamed appendix is in a pelvic location, adjacent to the right obturator internus muscle. The sensitivity of this maneuver for detecting appendicitis is very poor (at 8%), but the specificity is as high as 94%.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, and hypothyroidism presents with low back pain that developed last night while she was lifting boxes in her apartment. At that time, she felt a sharp pop in the back followed by acute onset of severe lumbar back pain. Over the next few hours, the pain began to radiate down both legs into her feet and became fairly severe. She took ibuprofen last night, but the pain has not improved. She requests hydrocodone because it helped with postsurgical shoulder pain last year. She has had no fever or incontinence, and she has no history of cancer.
Her physical examination is significant for absence of sensation in the perineum, bilateral mild foot drop, and reduced rectal tone. She is able to walk but seems to be in a lot of pain.
An emergency MRI of the lumbar spine shows a large posterior disk herniation at L5–S1 with complete effacement of the cauda equina.
In addition to hospitalization for monitoring, what is the most appropriate step next in management for this patient?

choices.text: Opioid analgesia and referral for elective spine surgery
Referral for emergency decompressive spine surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids could be considered while awaiting surgery, but the surgery should be done immediately, not electively.

B) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates multiple features consistent with cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is a surgical emergency due to compression of the nerve roots that form the cauda equina, causing back pain and radicular pain, motor and sensory deficits (which can be bilateral or unilateral), and dysfunction of the urinary and anal sphincters. It is commonly caused by disk herniation, as in this case, or by malignancy. Untreated CES can result in irreversible neurologic deficits; if it is suspected, the most appropriate diagnostic modality is an emergency MRI of the spine. If CES is confirmed, the most appropriate treatment is immediate surgical decompression.

Key learning point: In patients with acute neurologic deficits of cauda equina syndrome (severe low back pain with neurologic deficits), the appropriate treatment is emergency decompressive spine surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections are not indicated as initial treatments in cauda equina syndrome, because these interventions would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Vertebroplasty is not indicated as initial treatment in cauda equina syndrome, because this intervention would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Intensive physical therapy is not indicated as initial treatment in cauda equina syndrome, because it would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man reports 2 weeks of worsening pain in his lower back and right lower extremity. No injury or specific activity preceded the symptoms. The pain is worse with prolonged sitting and standing. He reports pain in his lateral leg and the dorsal aspect of his foot. He has had no recent fever, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, or bowel incontinence.
On examination, his lower-extremity strength is 5/5 with hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle plantar flexion and dorsiflexion. However, his great toe extension is diminished on the right compared with the left. He also has slightly diminished sensation to light touch on his anterior leg and dorsal foot. The straight-leg-raise test reproduces the radiating pain in his right leg.
Which one of the following findings would be expected when eliciting this patient’s lower-extremity deep-tendon reflexes on the symptomatic side?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A lumbar radiculopathy causes a lower motor neuron lesion, so the affected deep-tendon reflex is diminished and not increased.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has radicular low back pain. The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy; impingement of the L5 nerve root can be caused by a posterior L4–L5 disc herniation or a lateral L5–S1 disk herniation. Neither the patellar nor the Achilles reflex is affected by an L5 radiculopathy; these reflexes would therefore remain unchanged.

Key learning point: In a patient with an L5 radiculopathy, the patellar and Achilles reflexes are unchanged.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar radiculopathy causes a lower motor neuron lesion, so the affected deep-tendon reflex is diminished and not increased.

D) INCORRECT:

The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy. The Achilles reflex is not affected by an L5 radiculopathy and would therefore remain unchanged.

Impingement of the S1 nerve root would cause a diminished Achilles reflex, weakness with ankle plantar flexion, and/or numbness of the lateral ankle and foot.

E) INCORRECT:

The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy. The patellar reflex is not affected by an L5 radiculopathy and would therefore remain unchanged.

An impingement of the L4 nerve root would cause a diminished patellar reflex, weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, and/or numbness of the anterior knee extending to the medial ankle and foot.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents with chronic right arm pain and associated subacute, progressive weakness. The pain has been worsening for a few years, and the weakness has been worsening for 2 weeks. The pain, which the patient describes as deep and burning in the area of her right scapula with radiation to her neck and down her right arm, has limited her normal daily activities. Her symptoms improve when her right arm is elevated and flexed at the elbow.
Her neck, shoulder, and arm appear normal. She has mild tenderness to palpation of her right cervical paraspinal muscles. Her active and passive ranges of motion at the elbow and shoulder are normal. The rotator cuff has normal strength, biceps strength is 4/5, and wrist extension is 4/5. She has impaired sensation over the dorsal radial aspects of her thumb and forearm.
Neer, Hawkins, and Speed tests are normal. A Spurling test — involving cervical spine axial load, extension, and rightward rotation — exacerbates the pain.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parsonage-Turner syndrome is an idiopathic acute brachial plexopathy most commonly involving the suprascapular or long thoracic nerves. Affected patients report insidious unilateral shoulder pain associated with weakness involving shoulder abduction. Strength testing usually reveals supraspinatus weakness, scapular winging, or both. Clinical history and electromyography (EMG) confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome is associated with compression of nerves, blood vessels, or both by bony or muscular structures as they travel from the thorax to the upper extremity. Nerves are more commonly affected than vascular structures. The usual complaints are numbness and tingling in the hands and forearm, most commonly in the ulnar distribution. A Roos test is a provocative physical examination maneuver done with both of the patient’s shoulders abducted and elbows flexed to 90 degrees with arms overhead. Then the patient opens and closes the hands repeatedly for several minutes. A positive test reproduces symptoms. EMG or dynamic ultrasound can clarify the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome is an acute spinal cord injury involving weakness that is greater in the upper than in the lower extremities. It is more common in older patients with hyperextension injuries. The diagnosis of central cord syndrome is largely clinical, with support from advanced imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Shoulder impingement syndrome is more common in patients who do repetitive overhead activity that leads to inflammation of subacromial structures from the repetitive compression. Involved structures include the subacromial bursa and rotator-cuff tendons that traverse the subacromial space. Positive Neer and Hawkins tests support the diagnosis. These patients respond well to physical therapy and subacromial glucocorticoid injection.

E) CORRECT:

Degenerative cervical stenosis (and associated radiculopathy) is most common in older patients. It manifests as a chronic problem, with symptoms progressing from shoulder, neck, and extremity pain to extremity weakness to a myelopathy involving lower-extremity weakness, bowel and bladder symptoms, or gait changes. There is often tenderness to palpation of the cervical paraspinal muscles on the affected side and, sometimes, of the muscles innervated by the affected nerve root.

The foraminal compression test, or Spurling test, can detect cervical radiculopathy. It involves positioning the patient with the neck extended and the head rotated to the affected side, and then applying an axial load to the head. The test is positive if pain radiates into the limb ipsilateral to the side to which the head is rotated. The Spurling test has been found to be very specific (93%), but not sensitive (30%), in diagnosing acute radiculopathy.Therefore, it is not useful as a screening test, but it is clinically useful in helping to confirm cervical radiculopathy.

Key learning point: In an older adult with chronic progressive shoulder, neck, and arm pain associated with upper-extremity motor and sensory deficits, as well as a positive Spurling test, the most likely diagnosis is cervical stenosis and radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She appears healthy. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) typically manifests with radiating pain, paresthesias, and weakness. However, these symptoms are generally confined to the hand, specifically the palmar radial aspect, the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. Symptoms are often worse at night or after repetitive movements of the hand. The patient here does not have this pattern of symptoms. Additionally, a patient with CTS would not have pain in the neck or arm, weakness when extending the wrist (a sign of damage to the radial nerve or its corresponding cervical nerve roots), nor pain with Spurling's test.

B) INCORRECT:

A patient with degeneration of the spine between vertebral bodies C3 and C4 may experience damage to the C4 nerve root. If the C4 nerve root were damaged, a patient might describe pain and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of the neck or the interscapular region, difficulty elevating the shoulder, and/or dyspnea or shortness of breath, as C4 also innervates the diaphragm muscle.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient with syringomyelia would also likely present with radiating radicular pain, paresthesias, diminished reflexes, and weakness of the upper extremities. However, symptoms would be bilateral and usually include decreased sensation in a “cape-like” distribution secondary to the progressive compression and damage to crossing neural fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract. It would also manifest as flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy due to damage to the medial part of the corticospinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

A patient with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) may present with pain, paresthesias, and weakness of the upper extremity, often following overhead activity. However, rather than causing symptoms to one specific nerve root, TOS usually compresses the lower trunk (C8–T1 nerve roots) of the brachial plexus. In a patient with TOS, Spurling's test would not recreate the patient's symptoms because the test is relatively specific for damage/irritation of the cervical nerve roots rather than the brachial plexus. Furthermore, TOS often affects vascular structures as well; patients present with arm pallor, coldness, decreased pulses, and/or cyanosis of the affected extremity, none of which is present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has cervical radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation. Her radiating pain and paresthesias are caused by damage and/or irritation of the C6 nerve root, which innervates the radial aspect of the forearm and the thumb. These symptoms are reproduced with Spurling's maneuver, which has a high specificity for cervical radiculopathy. This patient's weakness results from damage to the same nerve root, as C6 provides motor function to the wrist extensors. C6 nerve root damage is also causing the decreased brachioradialis reflex in this patient, as C6 supplies motor function to that muscle.

Other possible causes of the patient's radiculopathy include cervical spondylosis or a tumor causing nerve root compression. Her neurologic symptoms may also be caused by infections that affect the peripheral nervous system such as herpes zoster and Lyme disease. The diagnostic workup includes MRI, which would show a laterally prolapsed disk with surrounding edema in the case of disk herniation.

Key learning point: C5-C6 disk herniation commonly causes C6 radiculopathy, presenting with neck and arm pain, sensory changes along the radial forearm and thumb, wrist extensor weakness, and decreased brachioradialis reflex.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathy

A herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.
questions.hint: The pattern of symptoms and exam findings indicate that a nerve root has been damaged.

questions.text: A 55-year-old carpenter reports worsening numbness in his right hand and difficulty using his tools for the past several weeks. He says that the numbness affects his fourth and fifth fingers specifically and that he cannot grip a hammer with sufficient strength. He also describes a shooting pain from the right shoulder and along the medial side of the right forearm. He has mild weakness of grip and finger extension of the right hand. There is no Tinel sign at the elbow. He has reduced perception of pinprick in the fifth finger of the right hand and the medial forearm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:
