A key step in evaluating a patient with neurologic problems is to localize the presenting problem to either the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or the peripheral nervous system (anterior horn cells, peripheral nerves, neuromuscular junctions, and muscles). When patients have weakness, the examiner can distinguish upper motor-neuron problems from lower motor-neuron problems by examining the pattern of the weakness, as well as function and dexterity, tone, tendon reflexes, and other signs.

This patient’s symptoms and signs (a distal weakness pattern, sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm, and no upper motor-neuron findings on examination) suggest a peripheral or lower motor-neuron neuropathy.

Medial hand and forearm sensory loss accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension and shooting pain from the shoulder to the hand is indicative of a C8 radiculopathy.

Key learning point: Sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension suggests a diagnosis of C8 radiculopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with an isolated ulnar neuropathy. Ulnar neuropathies are characterized by sensory loss limited to the hand, normal finger extension, and a Tinel sign at the elbow. Testing for Tinel sign at the elbow requires localization of the ulnar nerve in the groove between the olecranon process and the medial epicondyle of the elbow. The examiner’s index finger repeatedly taps the ulnar nerve, causing a tingling sensation in the ulnar distribution of the forearm and hand distal to the tapping point.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with stroke often have weakness in extensor more than flexor muscles and increased reflexes or tone, which indicates an upper motor-neuron lesion. This patient’s pattern of weakness together with his sensory symptoms points to a peripheral process.

D) INCORRECT:

A brachial plexus injury is unlikely to affect only the C8 muscles. Patients with superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumors often also present with Horner syndrome, a triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Horner syndrome indicates a problem with the sympathetic nervous system.

E) INCORRECT:

Median neuropathies, such as those that occur in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, manifest as sensory loss in the first three fingers.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of lower back pain for the past 2 weeks. The pain is stabbing and shooting in quality and radiates down the backs of his legs. It began when he was lifting a bag of cement at work. The pain has been getting worse, and he has started to notice occasional numbness and clumsiness while walking. Neurological examination shows 5/5 strength in the upper extremities and 3/5 strength in bilateral foot dorsiflexion. Sensation to light touch is diminished bilaterally over the lateral thigh area and the inner side of the lower legs. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the lumbar spine
Ibuprofen administration and follow-up in 2 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar x-ray is the first-line test for suspected vertebral compression fracture (e.g., history of osteoporosis). This patient does not have any significant risk factors for compression fractures. An x-ray of the spine has limited diagnostic value in patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation and is therefore not routinely recommended.

B) CORRECT:

MRI is a first-line test for diagnosing disk herniation with associated radiculopathy. In patients with progressive or severe motor deficits, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, or bilateral symptoms (as seen in this patient), an MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. In patients with disk herniation, T2 weighted MRI images typically show a hypointense disk with disk space narrowing and evidence of impingement or compression of a spinal nerve or the spinal cord (e.g., compression of the thecal sac, hyperintense edema of the spinal cord). If the patient has progressive neurological deficits, rapid assessment of the lesion is required and emergency surgical correction may be necessary.

While disk herniation is the most likely cause of this patient’s radiculopathy, an MRI would also help to rule out a neoplastic, infectious, inflammatory, or vascular etiology of his symptoms.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

The desiccated disk at L4–5 is hypointense and the disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

Hatched green overlay: normal intervertebral disks

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the spine without IV contrast is the initial imaging study for patients with suspected vertebral injury following blunt trauma (e.g., fall from height). In patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation, a CT scan has limited diagnostic value as it is not the best imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures. It may be indicated if first-line imaging is unavailable, but it is not the most appropriate imaging study.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral contrast; coronal plane)

A nonobstructive hyperdense calculus (red circle) is present in the left renal pelvis. Atherosclerotic calcifications (red arrowheads) of the abdominal aorta (red overlay) are also seen. Metal streak artifacts (white arrows) between the aorta and inferior vena cava (blue overlay) are caused by an internal spinal fixator.

K and dashed lines: kidney; Li: liver, Lu: lung; PM: psoas major muscle; S: stomach with oral contrast; UB: urinary bladder

D) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic exercise (e.g., physical therapy) is part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive neurological symptoms and motor weakness should raise concern for a complicated disk herniation. Exercise could worsen this condition, so a complicated disease should be ruled out first in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Analgesia (e.g., ibuprofen) and follow-up are part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive bilateral neurological symptoms and motor weakness instead raise concern for complicated disk herniation, so further investigation is required before conservative treatment would be indicated.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset back pain and sensorimotor dysfunction in a specific spinal nerve distribution that are accompanied by radicular pain (shooting down the leg) on the straight leg raise test is highly suggestive of lumbar disk herniation (likely L4).

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office 1 day after the sudden onset of pain in her neck, left shoulder, and left hand while shoveling snow. The pain improves when she lifts her left arm above her head. Muscle strength is 3/5 on elbow extension, wrist flexion, and finger extension of the left upper extremity. Triceps deep tendon reflex is 1+ in the left upper extremity and 2+ in the right upper extremity. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the index finger, middle finger, and radial half of finger IV of the left hand. An MRI of the cervical spine discloses a lateral disk herniation. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by compression of which of the following nerve roots?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

C4 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia affecting the lower neck and shoulder girdle (e.g., cape-like distribution), which is not the pattern seen here. Moreover, damage to the C4 nerve root leads to scapular winging, a condition that can arise due to any lesion to the dorsal scapular nerve innervating the rhomboid muscles. Finally, C4 radiculopathy does not cause a reduction in any of the reflexes of the upper extremity.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

C5 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia over the anterior shoulder, which is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. Moreover, damage to the C5 nerve root leads to impaired function of the biceps and deltoid muscles as well as a reduction in biceps reflex, none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

C6 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia extending from the radial aspect of the forearm to the thumb and radial side of the index finger, which is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. Moreover, damage to the C6 nerve root leads to impaired function of the biceps and wrist extensor muscles as well as a reduction in biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, none of which is seen here.

D) CORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain or paresthesia extending from the dorsal medial forearm up to the fingers II–IV and in palmar fingers II–IV (ulnar half of II, III entirely, radial half of IV). Damage to the C7 nerve root leads to impaired function of the triceps, wrist flexor, and finger extensor muscles as well as a reduction in triceps reflex.

The dermatomes overlap with each other and vary widely among individuals. Therefore, it may be difficult to identify the affected root only via sensory patterns, even in severe cases. Although the distribution of the sensory deficits is useful for the diagnosis, deficits are often not as characteristic as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

C8 radiculopathy typically manifests with ipsilateral pain and paresthesia extending from the dorsal forearm to the dorsal and palmar area of fingers IV (ulnar half) and V, and the hypothenar eminence, which is not the pattern seen here. Moreover, damage to the C8 nerve root leads to impaired function of the finger flexors and does not cause a reduction in any of the reflexes of the upper extremity.
questions.hint: Disk herniation and cervical spondylosis are the most common causes of compressive cervical radiculopathy. Some cervical roots are more frequently affected than others.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man reports 2 weeks of worsening pain in his lower back and right lower extremity. The pain is worse with prolonged sitting and standing. He reports pain in his lateral leg and the dorsal aspect of his foot. He has had no saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, or bowel incontinence. On examination, his lower-extremity strength is 5/5 with hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle plantar flexion and dorsiflexion. His great toe extension is diminished on the right compared with the left. He also has slightly diminished sensation to light touch on his anterior leg and dorsal foot. The straight-leg-raise test reproduces the radiating pain in his right leg. Which one of the following findings would be expected when eliciting this patient’s lower-extremity deep-tendon reflexes on the symptomatic side?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A lumbar radiculopathy causes a lower motor neuron lesion, so the affected deep-tendon reflex is diminished and not increased.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has radicular low back pain. The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy; impingement of the L5 nerve root can be caused by a posterior L4–L5 disc herniation or a lateral L5–S1 disk herniation. Neither the patellar nor the Achilles reflex is affected by an L5 radiculopathy; these reflexes would therefore remain unchanged.

Key learning point: In a patient with an L5 radiculopathy, the patellar and Achilles reflexes are unchanged.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar radiculopathy causes a lower motor neuron lesion, so the affected deep-tendon reflex is diminished and not increased.

D) INCORRECT:

The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy. The Achilles reflex is not affected by an L5 radiculopathy and would therefore remain unchanged.

Impingement of the S1 nerve root would cause a diminished Achilles reflex, weakness with ankle plantar flexion, and/or numbness of the lateral ankle and foot.

E) INCORRECT:

The clinical findings of weakness with great toe extension and numbness of the lateral leg and dorsal foot suggest an L5 radiculopathy. The patellar reflex is not affected by an L5 radiculopathy and would therefore remain unchanged.

An impingement of the L4 nerve root would cause a diminished patellar reflex, weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, and/or numbness of the anterior knee extending to the medial ankle and foot.
questions.hint: This patient would likely have difficulty in heel walking.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman reports low back pain and pain that radiates down her right leg to the top of her foot. The pain began suddenly one week ago during a strength-training class. She describes it as a moderately severe, deep, aching pain that is worsened by coughing, sneezing, and physical activity. Ibuprofen provides partial relief. She reports no weakness or numbness in her legs and no bowel or bladder dysfunction. On neurologic examination, she has normal muscle bulk, tone, and strength with preserved sensation. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most sensitive for the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patellar, or knee-jerk, reflex can be affected by pathology of the L2–4 nerve-root levels; the Achilles, or ankle-jerk, reflex is affected by pathology of the S1–2 nerve-root levels. Neither would be expected to be abnormal in an L5 radiculopathy, which is the most common lumbar radiculopathy and also the most consistent with this patient’s pain distribution.

B) CORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation is the most common cause of sciatica. On physical examination, a positive straight leg raise test is sensitive (although not specific) for disk herniation. The test is considered positive if sciatica (radicular pain extending to below the knee) is reproduced when the affected hip is flexed to 30 to 70 degrees with the knee extended.

If a patient’s symptoms, history, and physical examination are consistent with an uncomplicated lumbar disk herniation (i.e., there is no history of intravenous drug use, fever, an immunocompromised state, suspected malignancy, or fecal or urinary incontinence and no severe neurologic deficits on examination), immediate imaging is not required, and a 4- to 6-week trial of conservative management with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and exercise-based physical therapy can be undertaken.

Key learning point: The straight-leg-raise maneuver is a sensitive physical examination maneuver for lumbar disk herniation.

C) INCORRECT:

The contralateral straight-leg-raise test (flexion of the unaffected hip with the knee extended) is specific for lumbar radiculopathy but is not as sensitive as the straight-leg-raise test.

D) INCORRECT:

An extensor response to the plantar reflex, whereby the big toe moves superiorly and the other toes fan out in response to the sole of the foot being stroked with a blunt instrument, is a sign of corticospinal tract pathology (an upper motor-neuron pathology), which is not expected in cases of lumbar disk herniation (a lower motor-neuron pathology).

E) INCORRECT:

The obturator sign is an examination maneuver for appendicitis. Flexing and internally rotating the right hip can lead to pain if the inflamed appendix is in a pelvic location, adjacent to the right obturator internus muscle. The sensitivity of this maneuver for detecting appendicitis is very poor (at 8%), but the specificity is as high as 94%.
questions.hint: Acute, deep, aching pain radiating from the buttock down the lower extremity suggests sciatica.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis reports a deep, aching pain in his left buttock that began suddenly about 5 days ago, when he was helping his son move heavy furniture. The pain, which radiates down the back of his leg into the bottom of his foot, is aggravated by prolonged sitting and is relieved by lying down. The patient rates the current severity of the pain at 6 out of 10. He has had no significant weakness or difficulty walking. He is otherwise well and reports no bowel or bladder dysfunction, fever, or recent weight loss. On neurologic examination, he has normal muscle tone, bulk, and strength. The pain can be reproduced by a straight-leg-raise test at 50 degrees. The patient has no history of heart disease or peptic ulcer disease, and his laboratory results show normal renal function. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend that the patient stay active but avoid activities that exacerbate the pain, and consider prescribing nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs
Initiate an immediate-release opioid to be taken as needed for up to 6 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral for disk herniation is warranted only if there are severe neurologic deficits — or if a patient has not responded to conservative therapy and his MRI results confirm nerve-root compression corresponding to his clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with disk herniation are generally advised to stay active and avoid strict bed rest to prevent further debilitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections can be helpful in managing sciatica, but they are generally considered only after a 4- to 6-week trial if conservative therapy fails.

D) CORRECT:

Given that there are no severe neurologic deficits or findings in this case to suggest a more concerning etiology (e.g., history of intravenous drug use, immunocompromised state, malignancy, fecal or urinary incontinence), immediate imaging is not required, and the patient should be prescribed 6 weeks of conservative therapy consisting of activity modification (continuing physical activity but avoiding those activities that exacerbate the pain) and consideration of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (assuming no contraindications). Physical therapy is generally only recommended if the pain does not resolve with these initial measures, although there is some evidence that earlier physical therapy may be associated with better functional outcomes. Some clinicians might consider a short course of prednisone although available data suggest that this approach has only a very mild effect on pain and function.

Surgical referral is warranted only if there are severe neurologic deficits — or if a patient has not responded to conservative therapy and his MRI results confirm nerve-root compression corresponding to his clinical findings.

Key learning point: The initial management for uncomplicated sciatica is a conservative approach involving activity modification and consideration of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and physical therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Opioids should be avoided in the management of most causes of musculoskeletal pain, as studies have not shown any advantage over placebo and a higher rate of adverse effects.
questions.hint: This patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings, including a positive straight-leg-raise test, are consistent with uncomplicated disk herniation. Lumbar disk herniation is the most common cause of sciatica. Less common causes include spinal stenosis, vertebral fractures, tumors, and infections.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with chronic right arm pain and associated subacute, progressive weakness. The pain has been worsening for a few years, and the weakness has been worsening for 2 weeks. The pain, which the patient describes as deep and burning in the area of her right scapula with radiation to her neck and down her right arm, has limited her normal daily activities. Her symptoms improve when her right arm is elevated and flexed at the elbow. Her neck, shoulder, and arm appear normal. She has mild tenderness to palpation of her right cervical paraspinal muscles. Her active and passive ranges of motion at the elbow and shoulder are normal. The rotator cuff has normal strength, biceps strength is 4/5, and wrist extension is 4/5. She has impaired sensation over the dorsal radial aspects of her thumb and forearm. Neer, Hawkins, and Speed tests are normal. Tilting and rotating the neck toward the right side while applying downward pressure exacerbates the pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parsonage-Turner syndrome is an idiopathic acute brachial plexopathy most commonly involving the suprascapular or long thoracic nerves. Affected patients report insidious unilateral shoulder pain associated with weakness involving shoulder abduction. Strength testing usually reveals supraspinatus weakness, scapular winging, or both. Clinical history and electromyography (EMG) confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome is associated with compression of nerves, blood vessels, or both by bony or muscular structures as they travel from the thorax to the upper extremity. Nerves are more commonly affected than vascular structures. The usual complaints are numbness and tingling in the hands and forearm, most commonly in the ulnar distribution. A Roos test is a provocative physical examination maneuver done with both of the patient’s shoulders abducted and elbows flexed to 90 degrees with arms overhead. Then the patient opens and closes the hands repeatedly for several minutes. A positive test reproduces symptoms. EMG or dynamic ultrasound can clarify the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome is an acute spinal cord injury involving weakness that is greater in the upper than in the lower extremities. It is more common in older patients with hyperextension injuries. The diagnosis of central cord syndrome is largely clinical, with support from advanced imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Shoulder impingement syndrome is more common in patients who do repetitive overhead activity that leads to inflammation of subacromial structures from the repetitive compression. Involved structures include the subacromial bursa and rotator-cuff tendons that traverse the subacromial space. Positive Neer and Hawkins tests support the diagnosis. These patients respond well to physical therapy and subacromial glucocorticoid injection.

E) CORRECT:

Degenerative cervical stenosis (and associated radiculopathy) is most common in older patients. It manifests as a chronic problem, with symptoms progressing from shoulder, neck, and extremity pain to extremity weakness to a myelopathy involving lower-extremity weakness, bowel and bladder symptoms, or gait changes. There is often tenderness to palpation of the cervical paraspinal muscles on the affected side and, sometimes, of the muscles innervated by the affected nerve root.

The foraminal compression test, or Spurling test, can detect cervical radiculopathy. It involves positioning the patient with the neck extended and the head rotated to the affected side, and then applying an axial load to the head. The test is positive if pain radiates into the limb ipsilateral to the side to which the head is rotated. The Spurling test has been found to be very specific (93%), but not sensitive (30%), in diagnosing acute radiculopathy. Therefore, it is not useful as a screening test, but it is clinically useful in helping to confirm cervical radiculopathy.

Key learning point: In an older adult with chronic progressive shoulder, neck, and arm pain associated with upper-extremity motor and sensory deficits, as well as a positive Spurling test, the most likely diagnosis is cervical stenosis and radiculopathy.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive Spurling test.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old mechanic presents with a three-week history of gradually worsening right-sided neck pain radiating to the lateral aspect of his forearm and into the thumb. He reports numbness in the same distribution. He denies recent trauma or fever. Examination shows weakness in wrist extension, a diminished brachioradialis reflex, and limited neck rotation due to pain.
Which nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The C8 nerve root affects the medial forearm and hand, particularly the ring and little fingers. The patient's symptoms, including sensory disturbances in the lateral forearm and thumb, and weakness in wrist extension, do not fit the pattern of a C8 lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

The C5 nerve root typically innervates the shoulder region, contributing to shoulder abduction and sensation in the lateral shoulder. This patient's symptoms, including numbness in the lateral forearm and thumb, weakness in wrist extension, and a diminished brachioradialis reflex, do not align with a C5 lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy typically presents with pain radiating into the posterior forearm, sensory symptoms affecting the middle finger, and a diminished triceps reflex. The patient's sensory disturbances in the lateral forearm and thumb, along with a reduced brachioradialis reflex, do not support a C7 lesion.

D) CORRECT:

Cervical disc herniations at the C5-C6 level commonly affect the C6 nerve root. The patient's symptoms, including pain radiating to the lateral forearm and thumb, align with the C6 dermatome. The diminished brachioradialis reflex is a key indicator of C6 involvement. Although wrist extension involves overlapping myotomes, the sensory and reflex findings, along with the radicular pain pattern, are consistent with C6 radiculopathy.

Key learning point: Unilateral neck pain radiating to the shoulder and arm with numbness, weakness, and loss of tendon reflexes is indicative of cervical radiculopathy, often caused by cervical disc prolapse.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

questions.text: You are seeing a 47-year-old man in the emergency department who presents with urinary and fecal incontinence for the past 6 hours. Earlier today, he fell off a ladder at a construction site, injuring his back and thighs, but did not seek medical attention at that time. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. On examination, there is tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ at the ankles and 2+ at the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a distended bladder. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

B) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).

Key learning point: Conus medullaris syndrome presents with sudden bladder and bowel dysfunction, symmetric lower limb weakness, and mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs due to injury at the distal spinal cord.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to your clinic with progressively worsening lower back pain that radiates down her right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She reports no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which one of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?

choices.text: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia.
Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

Key learning point: S1 radiculopathy typically causes a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and sensory loss along the posterior calf and lateral foot.

B) INCORRECT:

Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

C) INCORRECT:

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

D) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.
questions.hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain and weakness in her lower extremities. The pain is aggravated by movement and improves when she lies flat. She was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis 6 months ago and is currently taking isoniazid and rifampin. On examination, there is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the lower thigh, patella, and medial aspect of the right lower leg. Strength with knee extension is 2/5, and the patellar reflex is absent. A spinal x-ray shows a paravertebral opacity with anterior wedging of the vertebral body. Which one of the following nerve roots is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

L4 radiculopathy characteristically manifests with sensory loss or paresthesia extending from the distal anterolateral thigh over the patella to the medial lower leg, as seen in this patient. Diminished knee extension would also be expected since innervation of the quadriceps is impaired. This patient's reduced patellar reflex further supports the diagnosis of impingement of the L4 nerve root as the underlying cause.

Key learning point: L4 radiculopathy causes sensory loss over the anterolateral thigh, patella, and medial lower leg, with weakness in knee extension and loss of the patellar reflex.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

B) INCORRECT:

S2 radiculopathy is relatively rare compared to other radiculopathies and may manifest with diminished sensation affecting the posterior aspect of the thigh, partly extending down to the posterior leg and the perineum. Moreover, affected individuals often have urinary or fecal incontinence and sexual dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically manifests with diminished sensation extending diagonally from the dorsolateral thigh over the lateral knee and the anterior leg to the dorsomedial side of the foot, including the medial toes. This pattern is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. In addition, an impinged L5 nerve root would not affect knee extension or the patellar reflex but would instead lead to impaired dorsiflexion of the foot due to impaired innervation of the tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus muscles.

D) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically manifests with sensory deficits involving the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, anterolateral as well as the posterolateral lower leg, and the lateral foot, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Moreover, an impinged S1 nerve root would not affect the patellar reflex but would instead lead to diminished ankle jerk reflex in combination with difficulty walking on toes due to impaired innervation of the gastrocnemius, peroneus longus, and peroneus brevis muscles.

E) INCORRECT:

L3 radiculopathy typically manifests with impaired sensation extending from the mid-anterolateral thigh to the medial thigh just above the patella, unlike the deficits seen in this patient. While affected individuals may present with a reduced adductor reflex and/or a mildly reduced patellar reflex along with mild impairment of knee extension, impaired hip flexion and adduction is more characteristic of L3 radiculopathy.
questions.hint: A history of radiculopathy symptoms in a patient with primary tuberculosis and x-ray findings of anterior wedging of the vertebral bodies and paravertebral opacity is suggestive of spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in his lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. Over the past week, he has also noticed decreased sensation around his buttocks and inner thighs, along with increased difficulty urinating. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago and received radiation therapy. Neurologic examination reveals reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; findings on the right are normal. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but squeeze tone is reduced. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.

Key learning point: Cauda equina syndrome presents with asymmetric lower limb weakness, saddle anesthesia, decreased reflexes, bladder dysfunction, and reduced anal sphincter tone, often due to compression below the L2 vertebral level.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent severe pain in the left neck, shoulder, and arm, as well as paresthesias in the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. When she extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she experiences paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness with left wrist extension against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patient with syringomyelia would also likely present with radiating radicular pain, paresthesias, diminished reflexes, and weakness of the upper extremities. However, symptoms would be bilateral and usually include decreased sensation in a “cape-like” distribution secondary to the progressive compression and damage to crossing neural fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract. It would also manifest as flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy due to damage to the medial part of the corticospinal tract.

B) INCORRECT:

A patient with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) may present with pain, paresthesias, and weakness of the upper extremity, often following overhead activity. However, rather than causing symptoms to one specific nerve root, TOS usually compresses the lower trunk (C8–T1 nerve roots) of the brachial plexus. In a patient with TOS, Spurling's test would not recreate the patient's symptoms because the test is relatively specific for damage/irritation of the cervical nerve roots rather than the brachial plexus. Furthermore, TOS often affects vascular structures as well; patients present with arm pallor, coldness, decreased pulses, and/or cyanosis of the affected extremity, none of which is present in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has cervical radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation. Her radiating pain and paresthesias are caused by damage and/or irritation of the C6 nerve root, which innervates the radial aspect of the forearm and the thumb. These symptoms are reproduced with Spurling's maneuver, which has a high specificity for cervical radiculopathy. This patient's weakness results from damage to the same nerve root, as C6 provides motor function to the wrist extensors. C6 nerve root damage is also causing the decreased brachioradialis reflex in this patient, as C6 supplies motor function to that muscle.

Other possible causes of the patient's radiculopathy include cervical spondylosis or a tumor causing nerve root compression. Her neurologic symptoms may also be caused by infections that affect the peripheral nervous system such as herpes zoster and Lyme disease. The diagnostic workup includes MRI, which would show a laterally prolapsed disk with surrounding edema in the case of disk herniation.

Key learning point: C5-C6 disk herniation causes C6 radiculopathy, presenting with neck and arm pain radiating to the thumb, sensory changes, wrist extensor weakness, and decreased brachioradialis reflex, often reproduced by Spurling’s maneuver.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathy

A herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.

D) INCORRECT:

A patient with degeneration of the spine between vertebral bodies C3 and C4 may experience damage to the C4 nerve root. If the C4 nerve root were damaged, a patient might describe pain and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of the neck or the interscapular region, difficulty elevating the shoulder, and/or dyspnea or shortness of breath, as C4 also innervates the diaphragm muscle.

E) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) typically manifests with radiating pain, paresthesias, and weakness. However, these symptoms are generally confined to the hand, specifically the palmar radial aspect, the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. Symptoms are often worse at night or after repetitive movements of the hand. The patient here does not have this pattern of symptoms. Additionally, a patient with CTS would not have pain in the neck or arm, weakness when extending the wrist (a sign of damage to the radial nerve or its corresponding cervical nerve roots), nor pain with Spurling's test.
questions.hint: The pattern of symptoms and exam findings indicate that a nerve root has been damaged.

questions.text: A 55-year-old carpenter comes to your clinic with worsening numbness in his right hand and difficulty using his tools over the past several weeks. He reports that the numbness specifically affects his fourth and fifth fingers, and he is unable to grip a hammer with sufficient strength. He also describes a shooting pain from his right shoulder down the medial side of his right forearm. On examination, there is mild weakness of grip and finger extension in the right hand. There is no Tinel sign at the elbow. Sensation to pinprick is reduced in the fifth finger and medial forearm on the right. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with an isolated ulnar neuropathy. Ulnar neuropathies are characterized by sensory loss limited to the hand, normal finger extension, and a Tinel sign at the elbow. Testing for Tinel sign at the elbow requires localization of the ulnar nerve in the groove between the olecranon process and the medial epicondyle of the elbow. The examiner’s index finger repeatedly taps the ulnar nerve, causing a tingling sensation in the ulnar distribution of the forearm and hand distal to the tapping point.

B) INCORRECT:

Median neuropathies, such as those that occur in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, manifest as sensory loss in the first three fingers.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with stroke often have weakness in extensor more than flexor muscles and increased reflexes or tone, which indicates an upper motor-neuron lesion. This patient’s pattern of weakness together with his sensory symptoms points to a peripheral process.

D) INCORRECT:

A brachial plexus injury is unlikely to affect only the C8 muscles. Patients with superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumors often also present with Horner syndrome, a triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Horner syndrome indicates a problem with the sympathetic nervous system.

E) CORRECT:

A key step in evaluating a patient with neurologic problems is to localize the presenting problem to either the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or the peripheral nervous system (anterior horn cells, peripheral nerves, neuromuscular junctions, and muscles). When patients have weakness, the examiner can distinguish upper motor-neuron problems from lower motor-neuron problems by examining the pattern of the weakness, as well as function and dexterity, tone, tendon reflexes, and other signs.

This patient’s symptoms and signs (a distal weakness pattern, sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm, and no upper motor-neuron findings on examination) suggest a peripheral orlower motor-neuron neuropathy.

Medial hand and forearm sensory loss accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension and shooting pain from the shoulder to the hand is indicative of a C8 radiculopathy.

Key learning point: Sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm accompanied by weakness of grip and finger extension suggests a diagnosis of C8 radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to your clinic with low back pain and pain radiating down her right leg to the top of her foot. The pain started suddenly one week ago during a strength-training class. She describes the pain as moderately severe, deep, and aching, and notes that it worsens with coughing, sneezing, and physical activity. Ibuprofen provides partial relief. She does not report any weakness, numbness in her legs, or bowel or bladder dysfunction. On neurologic examination, muscle bulk, tone, strength, and sensation are normal. Which one of the following physical examination maneuvers is most sensitive for the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation is the most common cause of sciatica. On physical examination, a positive straight leg raise test is sensitive (although not specific) for disk herniation. The test is considered positive if sciatica (radicular pain extending to below the knee) is reproduced when the affected hip is flexed to 30 to 70 degrees with the knee extended.

If a patient’s symptoms, history, and physical examination are consistent with an uncomplicated lumbar disk herniation (i.e., there is no history of intravenous drug use, fever, an immunocompromised state, suspected malignancy, or fecal or urinary incontinence and no severe neurologic deficits on examination), immediate imaging is not required, and a 4- to 6-week trial of conservative management with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and exercise-based physical therapy can be undertaken.

Key learning point: The straight-leg-raise maneuver is a sensitive physical examination maneuver for lumbar disk herniation.

B) INCORRECT:

An extensor response to the plantar reflex, whereby the big toe moves superiorly and the other toes fan out in response to the sole of the foot being stroked with a blunt instrument, is a sign of corticospinal tract pathology (an upper motor-neuron pathology), which is not expected in cases of lumbar disk herniation (a lower motor-neuron pathology).

C) INCORRECT:

The patellar, or knee-jerk, reflex can be affected by pathology of the L2–4 nerve-root levels; the Achilles, or ankle-jerk, reflex is affected by pathology of the S1–2 nerve-root levels. Neither would be expected to be abnormal in an L5 radiculopathy, which is the most common lumbar radiculopathy and also the most consistent with this patient’s pain distribution.

D) INCORRECT:

The obturator sign is an examination maneuver for appendicitis. Flexing and internally rotating the right hip can lead to pain if the inflamed appendix is in a pelvic location, adjacent to the right obturator internus muscle. The sensitivity of this maneuver for detecting appendicitis is very poor (at 8%), but the specificity is as high as 94%.

E) INCORRECT:

The contralateral straight-leg-raise test (flexion of the unaffected hip with the knee extended) is specific for lumbar radiculopathy but is not as sensitive as the straight-leg-raise test.
questions.hint: Acute, deep, aching pain radiating from the buttock down the lower extremity suggests sciatica.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man who is a construction worker with a history of heavy lifting presents with a 3-week history of lower back pain radiating to his left leg. He reports that the pain is most severe when he sits down at work and significantly improves when he stands up and walks around. Over the past week, he has noticed difficulty pushing off with his left foot when walking up stairs. Physical examination shows diminished left Achilles reflex and weakness with plantarflexion of the left foot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis typically causes neurogenic claudication with pain that is relieved by lumbar flexion such as sitting and worsens with lumbar extension during standing or walking. This patient's symptom pattern is the opposite of what is expected in spinal stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Piriformis syndrome can cause sciatic-type pain that may be exacerbated by sitting. However, isolated Achilles reflex loss and plantarflexion weakness are not expected with piriformis syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain typically causes localized back pain that may worsen with movement. It does not cause radicular symptoms, neurological deficits, or the specific pattern of pain worsening with lumbar flexion seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliac joint dysfunction typically causes localized lower back and buttock pain without radicular symptoms extending to the leg. A flexion-related pain pattern and neurological deficits such as reflex loss and motor weakness are not expected in sacroiliac joint dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Lumbosacral radiculopathy from degenerative disk disease characteristically worsens with lumbar flexion such as sitting and improves with lumbar extension during standing and walking. Diminished Achilles reflex and plantarflexion weakness indicate S1 radiculopathy, consistent with L5–S1 disk herniation. Difficulty with push-off when climbing the stairs further supports plantarflexion weakness from S1 nerve root compression.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of chronic lumbar pain presents with 18 hours of worsening bilateral leg weakness that began gradually after he lifted furniture. He reports difficulty starting urination and numbness around his buttocks. Physical examination shows 4/5 weakness in bilateral ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion, absent bilateral Achilles reflexes, and decreased sensation in the S2–S4 dermatomes. Post-void residual volume is 650 mL on bladder scan. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Lumbar spine x-ray with flexion-extension views
MRI lumbar spine with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs are useful for detecting gross bony abnormalities but cannot visualize soft tissue structures, including nerve roots and disc material, or evaluate for spinal cord compression. Plain radiographs are inadequate for evaluating suspected cauda equina syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

CT spine without contrast provides excellent bony detail but has limited sensitivity for soft tissue pathology. It cannot adequately assess disc herniation, nerve root compression, or spinal cord edema, which are essential for diagnosing cauda equina syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

CT myelogram is invasive and typically reserved for patients with contraindications to the first-line modality or when the first-line modality is not available.

D) INCORRECT:

Contrast enhancement is indicated when there is concern for malignancy, infection, or inflammatory conditions. For suspected cauda equina syndrome from degenerative causes, MRI without contrast provides adequate visualization of disc herniation and nerve compression.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation suggests cauda equina syndrome with bilateral lower motor neuron signs, saddle anesthesia, and urinary retention. MRI lumbar spine without contrast is the preferred initial imaging modality because it provides superior soft tissue detail to visualize disc herniation, nerve root compression, and spinal canal narrowing. Urgent imaging is essential because of the potential for permanent neurological damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who is a construction worker presents with severe left leg pain that started after lifting heavy equipment yesterday. The pain radiates from his lower back down the dorsolateral aspect of his left thigh and lower leg to the lateral foot. He reports that the pain worsens with sitting and improves slightly when walking. Examination shows weakness with toe walking and diminished left Achilles reflex. What additional motor deficit is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot dorsiflexion weakness is characteristic of L5 radiculopathy, which affects the tibialis anterior muscle.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- S1 radiculopathy affects both the peroneus longus and brevis muscles, causing foot eversion weakness, and the gastrocnemius muscle, causing plantarflexion weakness and difficulty with toe walking. The Achilles reflex is characteristically diminished in S1 radiculopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Big toe extension weakness indicates L5 radiculopathy affecting the extensor hallucis longus muscle.

D) INCORRECT:

Hip flexion weakness is characteristic of L3 radiculopathy and is accompanied by diminished adductor reflex rather than Achilles reflex.

E) INCORRECT:

Knee extension weakness is characteristic of L3–L4 radiculopathy, which affects the quadriceps muscle and is accompanied by diminished patellar reflex.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman who is an office worker presents with 5 days of progressive neck pain and numbness. She reports tingling in her thumb and index finger, with weakness when lifting her coffee cup. Physical examination reveals diminished biceps reflex and sensory loss over the lateral forearm extending to the thumb. Which physical examination maneuver is most appropriate to evaluate for nerve root compression?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Bragard sign is a modification of the straight leg raise test that involves dorsiflexion to reproduce lumbar radicular pain. This maneuver is specific to lumbosacral radiculopathy and is not useful for evaluating cervical nerve root compression.

B) INCORRECT:

The reverse straight leg raise test is used to assess upper lumbar nerve root compression through hip extension. This test is designed for lumbosacral radiculopathy evaluation and has no application in cervical spine pathology.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The Spurling maneuver involves tilting and rotating the neck toward the affected side while applying downward pressure to the head. This test screens for cervical radiculopathy by reproducing pain and paresthesia that radiates to the motor or sensory area of the affected nerve root. This patient's presentation with C6 distribution findings (biceps weakness, lateral forearm numbness to thumb) makes the Spurling maneuver the appropriate diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

The straight leg raise test evaluates lumbosacral radiculopathy by stretching lumbar nerve roots. This maneuver is inappropriate for cervical symptoms and does not provide diagnostic information about upper extremity nerve root compression.

E) INCORRECT:

The Hoffmann reflex assesses for cervical myelopathy by testing upper motor neuron function, not nerve root compression. A positive Hoffmann reflex suggests spinal cord compression rather than radiculopathy. This patient's unilateral lower motor neuron findings are consistent with radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who works in a warehouse presents with 3 days of worsening low back pain radiating down the left leg after lifting boxes. She reports difficulty walking on her heels and says that her left foot “slaps” when she walks. Examination shows weakness with first toe dorsiflexion and numbness extending from the lateral knee down the anterolateral leg to the dorsum of the foot. What is the most likely cause of this patient's functional deficit?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- L5 radiculopathy causes weakness of the tibialis anterior muscle, leading to difficulty with foot dorsiflexion and a resulting foot drop with heel walking impairment. The extensor hallucis longus weakness affects first toe dorsiflexion. Sensory deficits occur in the lateral thigh and knee, anterolateral leg, dorsum of foot, and big toe, matching this patient's presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

L3 radiculopathy affects hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction with sensory deficits in the anterolateral thigh area. This patient's foot drop and dorsal foot numbness are not consistent with L3 radiculopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

L4 radiculopathy causes knee extension weakness and sensory deficits in the anterolateral thigh, patella area, medial leg, and medial malleolus. This patient's lateral leg and dorsal foot symptoms do not match L4 distribution.

D) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy affects the peroneus muscles, mainly causing foot eversion weakness, and the gastrocnemius muscle, causing plantarflexion weakness with difficulty toe walking. The sensory distribution involves the dorsolateral thigh and leg and lateral foot, not the pattern described by this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

S2 radiculopathy causes sensory deficits in the posterior thigh and leg, not the lateral and dorsal distribution seen in this patient. Motor deficits in S2 radiculopathy are typically minimal and do not involve the muscles causing foot drop.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of progressive lower back pain and bilateral leg weakness that began after lifting heavy boxes. She reports new-onset difficulty with urination and bowel movements since yesterday. Physical examination shows bilateral lower extremity weakness, diminished sensation in the perineal area, and decreased rectal tone. What neurological finding best distinguishes the underlying pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary retention occurs in both spinal cord compression and cauda equina syndrome, though the timing and mechanism differ between these conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased rectal tone occurs in both spinal cord compression and cauda equina syndrome due to involvement of sacral nerve roots.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Hyperreflexia with upgoing toes indicates upper motor neuron dysfunction characteristic of spinal cord compression. Cauda equina syndrome manifests with lower motor neuron signs, including areflexia and absent Babinski responses.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilateral lower extremity weakness occurs in both spinal cord compression and cauda equina syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Perineal sensory loss can occur in both spinal cord compression and cauda equina syndrome. While saddle anesthesia is classically associated with cauda equina syndrome, sensory loss below the level of compression also occurs in spinal cord compression.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with lower back pain that began 8 hours ago while he was moving furniture. He reports bilateral leg weakness and numbness in his groin and inner thighs. Physical examination shows areflexic bilateral lower extremity weakness and decreased sensation in the S3–S5 dermatomes. A bladder scan shows 600 mL of urine. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT myelogram is invasive and typically reserved for patients with contraindications to the first-line modality or when the first-line modality is not available.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the lumbar spine is inferior to MRI for evaluating cauda equina syndrome. While CT can identify bony abnormalities, MRI provides superior visualization of soft tissue structures, disc herniation, and neural compression, which are essential for diagnosing compressive spinal emergencies.

C) INCORRECT:

While urgent surgical decompression is indicated for cauda equina syndrome, imaging must be obtained to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of neural compression before proceeding to surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are indicated for suspected malignant spinal cord compression but are not the initial priority in this patient's traumatic presentation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with cauda equina syndrome, evidenced by bilateral lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and urinary retention. Urgent MRI of the lumbar spine without contrast is the most critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of neural compression. This imaging directly determines the need for emergency surgical decompression to prevent permanent neurological damage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who is a construction worker presents with acute lower back pain radiating down his right leg after lifting heavy equipment. Examination shows decreased sensation over the dorsum of the right foot and weakness of right foot dorsiflexion. When the left leg is raised, the patient experiences pain in his right leg radiating to the dorsal foot and big toe. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate neurosurgical consultation is indicated for spinal cord compression, conus medullaris syndrome, or cauda equina syndrome. This patient shows isolated radiculopathy without features of any of these conditions, making surgical consultation premature.

B) INCORRECT:

While the crossed straight leg raise test is highly specific for lumbar nerve root lesions, urgent MRI is not indicated at this time. Conservative management with analgesics and physiotherapy is appropriate for patients with isolated radiculopathy and no red flags. Imaging can be considered if symptoms do not improve within 6 weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is considered for infectious or inflammatory causes of radiculopathy, which are not suggested by this patient's acute traumatic presentation. Lumbar puncture is not indicated for mechanical nerve root compression from disc herniation.

D) INCORRECT:

CT myelography is not the first-line imaging modality for suspected disc herniation with radiculopathy. This invasive procedure is typically reserved for patients in whom first-line imaging is contraindicated or provides inadequate visualization of neural structures. Moreover, imaging is not immediately indicated for isolated radiculopathy without red flags.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with isolated L5 radiculopathy without red flag features. Patients with isolated radiculopathy and no red flags should receive conservative management with analgesics and physiotherapy. Imaging can be considered if symptoms do not improve within 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who works in a warehouse presents with a 3-day history of lower back pain and left-leg symptoms following heavy lifting. He describes shooting pain from his lower back to his left knee, with numbness over the anterolateral thigh. Examination shows 4/5 strength with left hip flexion and knee extension. Straight leg raise test is positive at 45 degrees on the left. What combination of deep tendon reflex changes would be most consistent with this clinical presentation?

choices.text: Diminished Achilles and lateral hamstring reflexes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The perineal reflex is mediated by the S2–S4 nerve roots. S2–S4 radiculopathy manifests without significant motor deficits but with posterior thigh and leg numbness (S2), perineal numbness (S3–S4), and perianal numbness (S4). This patient likely has L3 radiculopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

The posterior tibial reflex is mediated by the L5 nerve root. L5 radiculopathy manifests with lateral thigh and leg numbness, foot dorsiflexion weakness with difficulty heel walking, and weakness of the extensor hallucis longus muscle. This patient likely has L3 radiculopathy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – L3 radiculopathy affects both the adductor and patellar reflexes. This patient's clinical presentation of anterolateral thigh numbness, hip flexion weakness, and knee extension weakness indicates L3 nerve root compression, typically from L2–L3 disk herniation. Both reflexes are mediated by the L3 nerve root and are typically diminished or absent in L3 radiculopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

The Achilles and lateral hamstring reflexes are both mediated by the S1 nerve root. S1 radiculopathy manifests with dorsolateral thigh and leg numbness, foot eversion and plantarflexion weakness, and difficulty with toe walking. This patient likely has L3 radiculopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated reduction of the patellar reflex is seen in L4 radiculopathy. This patient likely has L3 radiculopathy, which typically causes a different pattern of diminished deep tendon reflexes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of chronic lower back pain presents with acute worsening of pain following a lifting incident 8 hours ago. He reports bilateral leg weakness that is more pronounced on the right side. Physical examination shows decreased sensation over the buttocks and posterior thighs, diminished anal sphincter tone, and weakness in foot dorsiflexion bilaterally. He has not voided in 6 hours despite feeling the urge. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT lumbar spine with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Steroids may be considered for some causes of cord compression, such as malignancy, but IV corticosteroids are not indicated for cauda equina syndrome caused by mechanical compression from disc herniation.

B) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with NSAIDs and muscle relaxants is considered for simple radiculopathy without red flag features but is inappropriate for cauda equina syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

CT myelogram is invasive and only considered for suspected cauda equina syndrome when first-line imaging is contraindicated, inconclusive, or unavailable.

D) INCORRECT:

CT with contrast is not the preferred imaging modality for evaluating cauda equina syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of bilateral leg weakness, saddle anesthesia, decreased anal sphincter tone, and urinary retention strongly suggests cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is a neurological emergency that requires immediate confirmation with urgent MRI spine without contrast to guide emergency surgical decompression. Time is critical, as delayed treatment can result in permanent neurological deficits, including bowel and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of worsening neck pain that radiates down his left arm. He describes the pain as sharp, accompanied by a 'pins-and-needles' sensation in his thumb and index finger. The pain is exacerbated by turning his head to the left. On physical examination, he has 4/5 strength in left elbow flexion and wrist extension. Sensation is decreased over the lateral forearm and thumb. The left brachioradialis and biceps reflexes are 1+, while the triceps reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Deltoid and triceps strength are 5/5. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A herniated disk at the C5–C6 level typically compresses the exiting C6 nerve root. The classic presentation of a C6 radiculopathy includes neck pain radiating down the arm with sensory changes in the lateral forearm, thumb, and index finger. Motor deficits involve weakness of the muscles innervated by C6, primarily the biceps (elbow flexion) and wrist extensors. The brachioradialis reflex is also mediated by the C6 nerve root, and its diminishment is a key finding. This patient's clinical presentation of motor, sensory, and reflex deficits is consistent with a C6 nerve root lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome involves compression of the brachial plexus and/or subclavian vessels. Although it can cause arm pain and paresthesias, it most commonly affects the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1 roots). This leads to symptoms along the ulnar side of the forearm and hand (fourth and fifth digits), which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

A C6–C7 disk herniation is the most common type and compresses the C7 nerve root. A C7 radiculopathy typically manifests with weakness in elbow extension (triceps), wrist flexion, and finger extension. The sensory deficit classically involves the middle finger, and the triceps reflex is diminished. This patient has normal triceps strength and reflex, and the sensory changes are not in the C7 dermatome.

D) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist. It can cause paresthesias in the thumb and index finger. However, it does not cause neck pain, pain radiating from the neck, proximal motor weakness (elbow flexion), or reflex changes. The symptoms are also not typically exacerbated by neck movements.

E) INCORRECT:

A C4–C5 disk herniation compresses the C5 nerve root. Although this can cause neck pain and arm weakness, the deficits are different. A C5 radiculopathy typically causes weakness in shoulder abduction (deltoid muscle) and elbow flexion, with sensory loss over the lateral shoulder. The biceps reflex is diminished. This patient has normal deltoid strength and a sensory deficit in the forearm and hand, not the shoulder.
questions.hint: The combination of weakness in elbow flexion and wrist extension, sensory loss in the lateral forearm and thumb, and diminished brachioradialis and biceps reflexes is key to this patient's pathology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic with a 2-week history of severe low back pain that radiates down the posterior aspect of his right leg to the sole of his foot. The pain began acutely after he lifted a heavy box. He also reports numbness on the lateral side of his right foot. His symptoms are exacerbated by sitting and coughing. Physical examination shows weakness with plantar flexion of the right foot and a diminished right Achilles tendon reflex. A straight leg raise test on the right is positive, reproducing his pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Plain radiography of the lumbosacral spine
CT myelography of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are neurophysiologic tests that assess nerve and muscle function. Although they can confirm the presence and severity of a radiculopathy, they do not visualize the underlying anatomical cause. These studies are typically reserved for cases in which the diagnosis is unclear, to differentiate radiculopathy from other peripheral nerve disorders, or when clinical findings do not correlate with imaging results.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is characteristic of an S1 radiculopathy, most commonly caused by a herniated intervertebral disc. MRI is the diagnostic study of choice to confirm this diagnosis because of its superior ability to visualize soft tissues. It can directly identify the location and extent of disc herniation, nerve root impingement, and spinal stenosis. It can also effectively rule out other causes of nerve root compression, such as spinal tumors, epidural abscesses, or hematomas. Although imaging is not always required initially, it is indicated in patients with progressive or severe neurologic deficits, such as the motor weakness seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiography is useful for evaluating bony structures and can identify fractures, spondylolisthesis, or severe degenerative changes. However, it cannot visualize soft tissues such as intervertebral discs, nerve roots, or the spinal cord. Therefore, it cannot confirm the suspected diagnosis of a herniated disc causing nerve root compression.

D) INCORRECT:

CT myelography can effectively visualize the spinal canal and nerve roots to identify compression. However, it is an invasive procedure that requires a lumbar puncture to inject contrast dye and exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. It is generally considered a second-line imaging modality.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone scintigraphy is a nuclear medicine study that detects areas of increased bone turnover. It is highly sensitive for identifying metastatic disease, infection (e.g., osteomyelitis), or occult fractures. This patient's acute, mechanical-type injury without any red flags for malignancy or infection makes this study inappropriate for confirming a suspected disc herniation.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of symptoms, including pain radiating down the posterior leg, weakness with plantar flexion, and a diminished Achilles reflex, suggests compression of a specific lumbosacral nerve root.
